title: Psalms Chapter 75 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 75 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 75 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 75.

questions.question: To whom is thanks given in Psalms 75:1?
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:1 states, 'Unto thee, O God, do we give thanks.'

questions.question: Who will judge uprightly when receiving the congregation according to Psalms 75:2?
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:2 says 'When I shall receive the congregation I will judge uprightly,' referring to God as the judge.

questions.question: According to Psalms 75:3, what does God bear up?
options: The earth and all its inhabitants
questions.correctAnswer: The pillars of the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:3 states, 'I bear up the pillars of it,' referring to the pillars of the earth.

questions.question: In Psalms 75:4, who is told not to deal foolishly?
questions.correctAnswer: The fools
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:4 says, 'I said unto the fools, Deal not foolishly.'

questions.question: What warning is given in Psalms 75:5?
options: Lift not up your horn on high
questions.correctAnswer: Lift not up your horn on high
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:5 states, 'Lift not up your horn on high: speak not with a stiff neck.'

questions.question: From which directions does promotion NOT come according to Psalms 75:6?
questions.correctAnswer: East, West, and South
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:6 says, 'For promotion cometh neither from the east, nor from the west, nor from the south.'

questions.question: Who is described as the judge in Psalms 75:7?
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:7 states, 'But God is the judge: he putteth down one, and setteth up another.'

questions.question: What is described as being in the hand of the LORD in Psalms 75:8?
questions.correctAnswer: A cup
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:8 says, 'For in the hand of the LORD there is a cup, and the wine is red.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 75:8, who will wring out and drink the dregs of the cup?
options: All the wicked of the earth
questions.correctAnswer: All the wicked of the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:8 states, 'but the dregs thereof, all the wicked of the earth shall wring them out, and drink them.'

questions.question: Who will the Psalmist sing praises to forever according to Psalms 75:9?
questions.correctAnswer: The God of Jacob
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:9 says, 'But I will declare for ever; I will sing praises to the God of Jacob.'

questions.question: What will happen to the horns of the wicked according to Psalms 75:10?
questions.correctAnswer: They will be cut off
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:10 states, 'All the horns of the wicked also will I cut off.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 75:3 says that the earth and all its inhabitants are stable and unchanging.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:3 states, 'The earth and all the inhabitants thereof are dissolved,' indicating instability.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 75:7 declares that God sets up one and puts down another.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:7 says, 'But God is the judge: he putteth down one, and setteth up another.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 75:4 instructs the wicked to lift up their horn.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:4 says to the wicked, 'Lift not up the horn,' meaning they should not exalt themselves.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 75:1: 'Unto thee, O God, do we give _____.'
questions.correctAnswer: thanks
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:1 states, 'Unto thee, O God, do we give thanks.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 75 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 75 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 75, what biblical truth would you share about God's judgment and sovereignty?
options: God is the judge who sets down one and lifts up another
Promotion depends on human effort from the east or west
The earth and its inhabitants are stable and unshaken
Fools will always be exalted by God
questions.correctAnswer: God is the judge who sets down one and lifts up another
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:7 teaches that God is the judge who puts down one and sets up another. This highlights God's sovereign control over circumstances and encourages trust in His righteous judgment. Verses 3 and 6 also affirm God's sustaining power and that promotion does not come from human directions but from God.

questions.question: How does Psalms 75 teach us about humility when facing success or promotion in life?
options: Promotion does not come from the east, west, or south, but from God
One should boast loudly when promoted
Success is guaranteed for the wicked
Fools should lift up their horns proudly
questions.correctAnswer: Promotion does not come from the east, west, or south, but from God
questions.explanation: Verse 6 explains that promotion comes neither from the east, west, nor south, but from God alone. This teaches believers to be humble and recognize God as the source of all advancement, not human effort or pride. Verses 4 and 5 warn against foolish pride and speaking with a stiff neck.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with pride and arrogance. According to Psalms 75, what practical advice would you share about handling this challenge?
options: Do not lift up your horn on high or speak with a stiff neck
Boast about your achievements to make others respect you
Ignore God's judgment and trust in your own strength
Foolishness and wickedness will earn you promotion
questions.correctAnswer: Do not lift up your horn on high or speak with a stiff neck
questions.explanation: Verses 4 and 5 clearly instruct fools and the wicked not to act proudly or arrogantly by lifting up their horn or speaking with a stiff neck. This is a practical lesson in humility and obedience to God’s wisdom, encouraging believers to avoid pride and trust God's timing.

questions.question: What does Psalms 75 teach about God’s sustaining power during difficult times?
options: God bears up the pillars of the earth even when it dissolves
The earth and all its inhabitants are unshakable without God
We should rely on human strength to stand firm
The wicked control the foundation of the world
questions.correctAnswer: God bears up the pillars of the earth even when it dissolves
questions.explanation: Verse 3 states that though the earth and inhabitants dissolve, God bears up the pillars of it. This metaphor assures believers that God sustains and supports His creation and His people through trials, encouraging faith and perseverance.

questions.question: How does this passage encourage believers to respond in worship and gratitude?
options: To give thanks to God and sing praises forever
To only worship when we receive blessings
To remain silent about God's works
To depend on human wisdom for guidance
questions.correctAnswer: To give thanks to God and sing praises forever
questions.explanation: Verses 1 and 9 emphasize giving thanks to God and declaring praise forever. This encourages believers to cultivate a heart of gratitude and continual worship, recognizing God's nearness and wondrous works.

questions.question: In family or church life, how can this Psalm guide us in dealing with those who act foolishly or wickedly?
options: Warn them not to act foolishly or lift up their horn
Encourage them to boast about their success
questions.correctAnswer: Warn them not to act foolishly or lift up their horn
questions.explanation: Verses 4 and 5 instruct to tell fools and the wicked not to behave foolishly or arrogantly. This teaches believers to lovingly correct and guide others toward humility and obedience, fostering healthy community life.

questions.question: What does the imagery of the cup in God's hand (Psalms 75:8) teach us about God's justice?
options: God pours out judgment, and the wicked must drink the dregs
God’s cup is always full of mercy without judgment
The cup represents human control over justice
The wicked will never face consequences
questions.correctAnswer: God pours out judgment, and the wicked must drink the dregs
questions.explanation: Verse 8 uses the imagery of a cup full of mixed wine that God pours out, with the wicked wringing out and drinking the dregs. This symbolizes God's righteous judgment and that the wicked will face the consequences of their actions, encouraging believers to trust in divine justice.

questions.question: How does Psalms 75 encourage believers to maintain integrity and honesty in daily work?
options: Trust God’s judgment rather than worldly promotion
Use pride and arrogance to advance
Ignore God’s sovereignty in career matters
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God’s judgment rather than worldly promotion
questions.explanation: Verses 6 and 7 teach that promotion comes from God alone, not from worldly directions or manipulation. This encourages believers to maintain integrity and trust God’s timing and judgment rather than resorting to pride or dishonest means.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 75 teaches that the horns of the righteous will be exalted while those of the wicked will be cut off.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 10 states that all the horns of the wicked will be cut off, but the horns of the righteous shall be exalted. This symbolizes the triumph of the righteous and the downfall of the wicked, encouraging believers to live righteously.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 75, human efforts from the east, west, or south determine promotion and success.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 6 clearly states that promotion does not come from the east, west, or south but from God alone. This teaches believers to depend on God rather than human efforts for success.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "Unto thee, O God, do we give thanks, unto thee do we give thanks: for that thy name is ______; thy wondrous works declare."
questions.correctAnswer: near
questions.explanation: Verse 1 says, "for that thy name is near; thy wondrous works declare." This expresses God's closeness and involvement in the lives of His people, encouraging gratitude and trust.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to boast after receiving a promotion. Based on Psalms 75, what biblical principle should guide them?
options: Promotion comes from God, so humility is due
Boast loudly to show your success
Ignore God’s role in your advancement
Use the promotion to elevate yourself above others
questions.correctAnswer: Promotion comes from God, so humility is due
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:6-7 highlight that promotion comes from God, not from human directions. This teaches believers to respond with humility, recognizing God's sovereignty over their success and avoiding pride.

questions.question: How does Psalms 75 encourage believers to pray and worship in response to God's works?
options: To give thanks and sing praises forever
To only worship privately without praise
To depend on human wisdom alone
questions.correctAnswer: To give thanks and sing praises forever
questions.explanation: Verses 1 and 9 emphasize giving thanks to God and singing praises forever, encouraging believers to maintain a lifestyle of prayerful gratitude and joyful worship recognizing God's deeds.

questions.question: A church leader must judge fairly when receiving a congregation. What does Psalms 75 say about this responsibility?
options: Judge uprightly when receiving the congregation
Favor the strong and ignore the weak
questions.correctAnswer: Judge uprightly when receiving the congregation
questions.explanation: Verse 2 states, "When I shall receive the congregation I will judge uprightly," teaching the importance of fairness and integrity in leadership, encouraging leaders to judge with righteousness.

questions.question: How can Psalms 75 guide believers to persevere through trials and temptations?
options: Trust that God sustains the world and will uphold the righteous
Rely solely on personal strength to overcome
Ignore God's justice and continue sinning
questions.correctAnswer: Trust that God sustains the world and will uphold the righteous
questions.explanation: Verse 3 affirms God's sustaining power over the earth and its pillars. This encourages believers to trust God’s strength and faithfulness during trials, knowing He will uphold and exalt the righteous (verse 10).

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 75 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 75.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in Psalms 75:4-5 when addressing the fools and the wicked about lifting up their horns?
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor
questions.explanation: The phrase 'Lift not up your horn' uses horn as a metaphor for power or pride, a common Hebrew metaphor for strength and exaltation, as seen in Psalms 75:4-5.

questions.question: In Psalms 75:3, the earth and its inhabitants are described as dissolved. What does the phrase 'I bear up the pillars of it' imply in the ancient Near Eastern cosmology?
options: The earth is made of pillars
questions.correctAnswer: God sustains the world’s stability
questions.explanation: The pillars symbolize foundational supports of the earth, reflecting ancient Near Eastern imagery of the cosmos. The verse shows God's role in sustaining creation, Psalms 75:3.

questions.question: Which of the following best captures the theological theme of divine sovereignty expressed in Psalms 75:6-7?
questions.correctAnswer: God alone judges and exalts
questions.explanation: Verses 6 and 7 emphasize that promotion does not come from human directions or powers but solely from God’s judgment and authority.

questions.question: In Psalms 75:8, what is the symbolic meaning of the 'cup' and the 'red wine full of mixture' in the hand of the LORD?
options: A symbol of joy and blessing
A cup of wrath and judgment
questions.correctAnswer: A cup of wrath and judgment
questions.explanation: The cup symbolizes God's judgment poured out on the wicked, a common biblical image seen also in Isaiah 51:17 and Revelation 14:10, as shown in Psalms 75:8.

questions.question: How does the imagery of 'cutting off the horns' in Psalms 75:10 relate to Old Testament symbolism of power and authority?
options: Horns represent animals used in sacrifice
Horns are a symbol of wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Horns symbolize strength and power
questions.explanation: In ancient Near Eastern symbolism, including the Bible, horns often represent power or strength. Cutting off the horns of the wicked indicates removal of their power (Psalms 75:10).

questions.question: What aspect of divine justice is highlighted by the phrase 'I will judge uprightly' in Psalms 75:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Impartial and righteous judgment
questions.explanation: The psalmist declares God's judgment as upright, meaning just and fair, reflecting the biblical theme of God's righteousness (Psalms 75:2).

questions.question: The phrase 'unto thee do we give thanks' is repeated in Psalms 75:1. What Hebrew poetic device is illustrated by this repetition?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Repetition of similar phrases for emphasis is a characteristic of Hebrew parallelism, a common poetic device in Psalms (Psalms 75:1).

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 75 suggests that human promotion and exaltation come from political or geographical regions such as the east, west, or south.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:6 explicitly denies that promotion comes from any human direction or region, stating it comes only from God.

questions.question: The use of 'Selah' in Psalms 75:3 is thought to serve what purpose in the structure of the psalm?
options: A musical pause or reflection point
questions.correctAnswer: A musical pause or reflection point
questions.explanation: Selah is believed to mark a pause for contemplation or musical interlude, enhancing the meditative quality of the psalm (Psalms 75:3).

questions.question: Which New Testament concept echoes the idea in Psalms 75:7 that 'he putteth down one, and setteth up another'?
options: The Parable of the Mustard Seed
Jesus’ teaching on humility and exaltation
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus’ teaching on humility and exaltation
questions.explanation: Jesus taught that those who humble themselves will be exalted, paralleling the psalm’s theme of God’s sovereign judgment (cf. Luke 14:11) (Psalms 75:7).

questions.question: How does the psalmist’s declaration in Psalms 75:9, 'I will sing praises to the God of Jacob,' reflect the covenantal relationship theme in Scripture?
options: It emphasizes God's faithfulness to Israel
It is a call for universal worship
It signifies the end of the covenant
It refers to a new covenant only
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes God's faithfulness to Israel
questions.explanation: The God of Jacob refers to the covenant God made with Israel's patriarchs, highlighting faithfulness and praise within this relationship (Psalms 75:9).

questions.question: In Psalms 75:8, the phrase 'the dregs thereof, all the wicked of the earth shall wring them out, and drink them' foreshadows what biblical motif seen in prophetic literature?
questions.correctAnswer: The cup of God’s wrath
questions.explanation: This imagery is a prophetic motif of the wicked receiving God's judgment, similar to passages in Jeremiah 25 and Revelation 16 (Psalms 75:8).

questions.question: What is the significance of addressing the psalm 'To the chief Musician, Altaschith' as in Psalms 75:1?
options: Indicates a specific musical style or tune
Refers to a type of offering
questions.correctAnswer: Indicates a specific musical style or tune
questions.explanation: Altaschith means 'Do Not Destroy,' likely a musical direction or tune to which the psalm was to be performed (Psalms 75:1).

questions.question: How does the warning to 'speak not with a stiff neck' in Psalms 75:5 relate to the broader biblical theme of humility?
questions.correctAnswer: It condemns arrogance and rebellion
questions.explanation: 'Stiff neck' is a biblical metaphor for pride and rebellion against God, reinforcing the call for humility (Psalms 75:5).

questions.question: Which aspect of Psalms 75 aligns with the prophetic tradition of divine judgment found in books like Isaiah and Jeremiah?
options: The call to worship with instruments
The depiction of God’s cup of wrath and judgment
questions.correctAnswer: The depiction of God’s cup of wrath and judgment
questions.explanation: The cup imagery in Psalms 75:8 reflects the prophetic theme of divine judgment on the wicked, common in Isaiah and Jeremiah.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 75 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 75 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 75:1, why do the faithful give thanks to God?
options: Because His name is near and His wondrous works declare
Because He answers all prayers immediately
questions.correctAnswer: Because His name is near and His wondrous works declare
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:1 explicitly states that thanks are given because God's name is near and His wondrous works declare it, showing His active presence and mighty deeds. Similarly, Exodus 34:6-7 reveals God's attributes, and Psalm 105:1 calls to give thanks for His wondrous works. In the New Testament, 1 Thessalonians 5:18 commands giving thanks in all circumstances, and Revelation 19:7 rejoices in God's righteous acts.

questions.question: What role does God fulfill when He "receives the congregation," as stated in Psalms 75:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Judge who executes upright judgment
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:2 highlights God's role as Judge who judges uprightly when receiving the congregation. This aligns with Deuteronomy 32:4, which describes God as a God of justice. In John 5:22, Jesus states the Father has given Him authority to judge, and Romans 14:10 calls all to stand before God's judgment seat. Hebrews 12:23 speaks of the assembly of the firstborn, linking the congregation to divine judgment.

questions.question: In Psalms 75:3, what does God say about the earth and its inhabitants?
options: They are dissolved, but He upholds the pillars
They are under the dominion of angels
They are destined for destruction without hope
questions.correctAnswer: They are dissolved, but He upholds the pillars
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:3 declares the earth and its inhabitants dissolve, yet God upholds the pillars, demonstrating His sustaining power over creation. This parallels Hebrews 1:3, where Christ upholds all things by His word. Isaiah 40:8 contrasts the fading earth with God's word, and Colossians 1:17 affirms Christ's sustaining role. Revelation 21:1 speaks of a new earth, showing the temporal nature of the current creation.

questions.question: What warning is given to the fools and the wicked in Psalms 75:4?
options: Do not deal foolishly or lift up the horn
Ignore the counsel of the wise
questions.correctAnswer: Do not deal foolishly or lift up the horn
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:4 warns fools and wicked not to act foolishly or arrogantly ('lift up the horn'). This horn symbolizes pride and power, echoed in Proverbs 16:18 about pride leading to destruction. Isaiah 10:12 shows God humbling the arrogant, and James 4:6 states God opposes the proud. 1 Peter 5:5 encourages humility before God’s exaltation.

questions.question: What does Psalms 75:6 teach about the source of promotion and exaltation?
options: Promotion comes only from God, not from east, west, or south
Promotion depends on human effort and alliances
Promotion is granted by earthly kings
Promotion comes through wisdom and knowledge
questions.correctAnswer: Promotion comes only from God, not from east, west, or south
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:6 emphasizes promotion does not come from any earthly direction but solely from God. This teaches God’s sovereign control over human affairs. Daniel 2:21 affirms God sets up and removes kings. Proverbs 21:1 describes God directing rulers’ hearts. James 4:10 calls believers to humble themselves before God who will exalt them, and 1 Samuel 2:7 declares God raises the poor and brings down the proud.

questions.question: According to Psalms 75:7, what is God's role concerning those who are exalted or brought low?
options: God is the judge who puts down one and sets up another
God remains neutral in human affairs
God rewards only the wealthy and powerful
God allows fate to determine status
questions.correctAnswer: God is the judge who puts down one and sets up another
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:7 states God as judge acts decisively in elevating or humbling individuals. This reflects themes in 1 Samuel 2:6-7, where God raises and casts down. Proverbs 3:34 says God opposes the proud but gives grace to the humble. Luke 1:52 speaks of God bringing down the mighty and exalting the lowly. Romans 9:21 uses the potter and clay analogy, showing God's sovereign authority.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'cup' in the hand of the LORD described in Psalms 75:8?
options: It symbolizes God's judgment and wrath poured out on the wicked
It represents God's covenant with Israel
It is a symbol of God's provision and blessing
It signifies the Holy Spirit's presence
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes God's judgment and wrath poured out on the wicked
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:8 describes a cup full of mixed wine in God's hand, representing the outpouring of His judgment on the wicked. This metaphor parallels Revelation 14:10 and 16:19 where God's wrath is depicted as a cup of wine. Jeremiah 25:15-16 also uses the cup imagery for divine wrath. Isaiah 51:17 speaks of the cup of God's fury. The New Testament uses the cup symbolically in Matthew 26:39 regarding suffering but here it denotes judgment.

questions.question: In Psalms 75:10, what will happen to the 'horns' of the wicked versus the righteous?
options: The horns of the wicked will be cut off; the horns of the righteous will be exalted
The horns of the righteous will be cut off; the wicked will be exalted
Neither will be exalted or cut off
questions.correctAnswer: The horns of the wicked will be cut off; the horns of the righteous will be exalted
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:10 contrasts the fate of the wicked and righteous using the imagery of horns symbolizing strength and power. The wicked's power will be removed, while the righteous will be exalted. This theme appears in 1 Samuel 2:1-10, where God lifts the humble and casts down the wicked. Luke 1:52 echoes God scattering the proud and exalting the humble. Proverbs 10:27 associates fear of the Lord with life, and Revelation 5:5 refers to Christ as the Lion, a horn of salvation.

questions.question: Who is attributed as the author or associated figure of Psalms 75, as stated in Psalms 75:1?
questions.correctAnswer: Asaph
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:1 attributes the Psalm to Asaph, a prominent temple musician and seer. Asaph is credited with several Psalms (e.g., Psalms 73, 82). David is the author of many Psalms but not this one. Solomon and Moses wrote other biblical songs or Psalms but are not attributed here. 1 Chronicles 16:7-36 references Asaph’s role in worship and Psalm authorship.

questions.question: What does Psalms 75:5 mean by 'speak not with a stiff neck' in its admonition?
options: Do not be stubborn or rebellious
Do not speak loudly in anger
Do not speak to those in authority
questions.correctAnswer: Do not be stubborn or rebellious
questions.explanation: The phrase 'speak not with a stiff neck' in Psalms 75:5 metaphorically calls for humility and warns against stubbornness or rebellion against God’s authority. This imagery appears in Exodus 32:9-10, where Israel is described as stiff-necked. Proverbs 29:1 links stubbornness to punishment. Jeremiah 7:26 and Acts 7:51 use similar language to describe resistance to God’s word. The New Testament encourages humble submission (James 4:7).

questions.question: What theological truth is underscored by the statement in Psalms 75:9, 'I will declare forever; I will sing praises to the God of Jacob'?
options: The eternal praise and faithfulness to God's covenant people
That praise is only for a limited time
That God's promises are conditional on human merit
That worship is only for the temple priests
questions.correctAnswer: The eternal praise and faithfulness to God's covenant people
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:9 expresses a commitment to eternal praise directed to the God of Jacob, emphasizing God's enduring covenant relationship with His people. This is consistent with Genesis 28:13-15 where God promises to bless Jacob’s descendants. Psalm 89:28 speaks of God's covenant forever. Hebrews 6:13-18 affirms God's unchanging purpose, and Revelation 5:13 describes unending worship of God. This illustrates the doctrine of God's faithfulness and covenantal grace.

questions.question: How does Psalms 75:8 describe the characteristics of the cup in God's hand?
options: Red wine, full of mixture, poured out on the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: Red wine, full of mixture, poured out on the wicked
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:8 describes the cup in God's hand as red wine, full of mixture, symbolizing the complex and potent judgment He pours out on the wicked. This aligns with Revelation 14:10 and Jeremiah 25:15 where God's wrath is depicted as a cup of wine. The mixed wine suggests severity and fullness of wrath. Isaiah 51:17 also uses this imagery. It contrasts with blessings symbolized by oil or honey in other scriptures (Psalm 23:5, Proverbs 24:13).

questions.question: What does Psalms 75:4-5 collectively warn against regarding the attitude of the wicked?
questions.correctAnswer: Pride, arrogance, and foolishness
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:4-5 warns the wicked and fools not to act foolishly, lift up their horn (symbolic of pride), or speak with a stiff neck, which indicates arrogance. This teaches that pride leads to judgment (Proverbs 16:18). Humility is encouraged in scriptures like James 4:6 and 1 Peter 5:5. The contrast between pride and humility is a consistent biblical theme (Isaiah 2:12, Luke 14:11).

questions.question: Which theological attribute of God is most emphasized in Psalms 75:7?
options: God's justice and sovereignty as Judge
questions.correctAnswer: God's justice and sovereignty as Judge
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:7 highlights God's sovereign authority and justice as Judge who exalts and humbles at His will. This attribute is foundational in the doctrine of God's righteous governance (Psalm 89:14, Isaiah 33:22). Romans 2:5-6 affirms God’s righteous judgment. Deuteronomy 32:4 declares God’s perfect justice. This underscores God’s control over human destinies reflecting divine sovereignty.

questions.question: According to Psalms 75:3, what metaphor illustrates God’s sustaining power over the earth?
options: He bears up the pillars of the earth
He commands the seas to be still
He stretches out the heavens like a curtain
He plants trees in the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: He bears up the pillars of the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 75:3 uses the metaphor of God bearing up the pillars of the earth to illustrate His sustaining power. This reflects God's providential care, similar to Job 26:11 and Proverbs 8:28 describing God's foundation of the earth. Hebrews 1:3 teaches Christ sustains all things by His word. Isaiah 40:22 describes God as the one who stretched out the heavens, also showing creative power but sustaining is the key here.
